title: 112_s3236
content: The Act titled "Servicemember Employment Protection Act of 2012" prohibits agreements to arbitrate disputes arising under USERRA. The "Servicemember Employment Protection Act of 2012" prohibits agreements to arbitrate disputes arising under USERRA. Subchapter III of title 38, United States Code, now includes a section stating that any agreement between an employer and an employee mandating arbitration of disputes under this chapter is unenforceable, except in certain circumstances. The validity or enforceability of an arbitration agreement shall be determined by Federal law, with courts making the decision regardless of challenges. This section applies to all contracts between employers and employees, both existing and future agreements. Section 4328 of title 38, United States Code, addresses the unenforceability of agreements to arbitrate disputes. It applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all actions filed under chapter 43. Additionally, Section 3 expands employment and reemployment rights for members of the uniformed services to include protection for absences related to service-connected medical treatment. Section 4303(13) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include absences for medical or dental treatment related to duty in the uniformed services. This amendment clarifies that such absences are not considered as leave under the FMLA. The term "covered provision" in this subsection refers to specific laws including the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and subchapter V of chapter 63 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. Suspension, termination, or debarment of contractors for repeated violations of employment or reemployment rights of members of uniformed services. Section 4329 of title 38, United States Code, allows for the suspension, termination, or debarment of contractors who repeatedly fail to comply with employment rights of members of the uniformed services. The contracting officer can initiate appropriate actions if cause for suspension or termination is determined. Debarment actions can be initiated by agencies for non-compliance with employment rights of uniformed services members. Contractors debarred are ineligible for federal contracts for up to 5 years. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation within 180 days to implement section 4329 of title 38, United States Code. Section 4329 applies to failures to comply with chapter 43 of the title after the enactment of this Act.
